intro: Monolophus larsenii, commonly known as the Larsen's larkspur, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is characterized by its tall, sparsely branched stems and clusters of blue to purple flowers. The plant has lance-shaped leaves that are often hairy and arranged alternately along the stem. It thrives in rocky, well-drained soils and is typically found in open habitats such as meadows and slopes. Monolophus larsenii is part of the Ranunculaceae family, which includes many toxic plants, and it contains alkaloids that can be harmful to livestock and humans.
